name: Duwamish Longhouse and Cultural Center
description: ancestral site of Seattle's first people

name: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park
Kubota Garden
description: This semi-secret garden in south Seattle emulates a traditional Japanese garden using the plants of the Pacific Northwest.

name: Big Top Curiosity Shop
description: Inside this curiosity shop, visitors can peruse the clown collection or purchase a molar from the mouth of Bigfoot.

name: Dunn Gardens
description: A lush Seattle garden designed by the same landscape architects responsible for New York's Central Park.

name: Connections Museum
description: This Seattle museum displays the history of the telephone through an impressive collection of telecom equipment.  The museum is open to the public every Sunday from 10 am to 3 pm.

name: Hat & Boots Park (Oxbow Park)
description: Seattle's super-sized cowboy apparel once belonged to a themed gas station that wrangled in herds of tourists.

name: Georgetown Steam Plant
description: A frozen relic of Seattle's hydroelectric boom is now a teaching facility for future engineers.

name: Ye Olde Curiosity Shop
description: A 100-year-old purveyor of curiosities, curios, and kitsch featuring mummies, shrunken heads, and a Fiji Mermaid.

name: Museum of Pop Culture
description: A museum dedicated to the history and exploration of both popular music and science fiction.

name: Howe Street Stairs - Top
description: longest of seattle's 560 public stairways; Spanning an elevation of 160 feet and containing 388 steps, this is Seattle's longest staircase.

name: "Sound Garden" by Douglas Hollis
description: A huge musical sculpture and other art installations on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration grounds.

name: Seattle Pinball Museum
description: Couple's personal collection of pinball machines turned public pinball museum.

name: Arctic Club Hotel
description: The historic bar where local ship captains, traders, and gold miners would come together to do business a century ago.

name: Ars Obscura Bookbinding & Restoration
description: In this subterranean brick arcade, a small shop continues the ancient practice of bookbinding.

name: Edith Macefield House
description: famous holdout housel The tale of a strong-willed woman who stood her ground when the commercial world came rumbling in.

name: Beacon Food Forest
description: This edible park is open to any and all foragers.

name: Freeway Park
description: The first park built over a freeway is a brutalist masterwork.

name: Ballyhoo Curiosity Shop
description: This Seattle store is packed with all sorts of curious creatures and creations.

name: Add-A-Ball
description: A (slightly) grownup take on the classic retro arcade.

name: Suzzallo and Allen Libraries
description: With its vaulted ceiling and gilded details, this University of Washington library would feel right at home inside an old palace.

name: Washington Park Arboretum
description: The Olmsted Brothers-designed Washington Park Arboretum covers a highly-explorable 230 acres, including the Japanese Garden and many wild, heavily canopied areas, each with their own distinct vegetation. It’s a popular spot for canoeing or kayaking, too.

name: Volunteer Park Conservatory
description:
On the other side of the park from the water tower, the Volunteer Park Conservatory is the perfect place for an all-weather nature walk. Located inside a temperature-controlled Victorian-style glass house built in 1912, the botanical garden features a wide variety of plants, including a couple of plants more than 75 years old: a sago palm and a jade tree.

While you’re in Volunteer Park, climb up the winding staircase to the top of the 1906-built water tower for a 360-degree view of the city.

name: Neukom Vivarium
description: A rotting tree in the middle of Seattle doubles as an elaborately-controlled art piece.

name: Rhododendron Species Botanical Garden
description: This 22-acre botanical garden is home to the largest collection of rhododendrons in the world.

name: Pacific Bonsai Museum
description: A comprehensive collection of bonsai set in a beautiful campus.

name: King Street Station
description: Designed by Charles Reed and Allen Stem and built in 1906, the station’s 250-foot clock tower was modeled after Venice, Italy’s Piazza de San Marco’s bell tower. If you haven’t been for a few years, it’s worth a second look: A renovation completed between 2008 and 2014 uncovered ornate ceilings, wainscoting and mosaic tile work hidden after an unfortunate redesign in the 1960s.

name: Dr. Jose Rizal Park
description: Named for beloved Filipino figure José Rizal, this Beacon Hill park has one of the most spectacular—and totally underrated—views of downtown Seattle.

name: Bullitt Center
description: greenest building in the world (allegedly)

name: Fourth And Madison Building
description: rooftop garden on 7th floor

name: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Discovery Center
Henry Art Gallery
description: home to James Turrell's Skyspace: An enclosed rotunda at the Henry Art Gallery in which viewers can look up and see the uninterrupted sky.

name: Jack Perry Memorial Park
description: where to watch the giant container cranes at the port

name: Jack Block Park View Point
description: maybe better place to see the port

name: Seattle Chinese Garden
description: This beautiful landscape is the only Sichuan-style garden outside of China.

name: Peter Miller Architecture And Design Books
Old Seattle Paperworks
description: Giant Shoe Museum

name: Mudlark Oddities
description: A hidden gem full of oddities, curiosities and macabre antiques.

name: Green Lake Boathouse and Coffee Shop
Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture
description: ichthyology collection: This remarkable collection devoted to the study of fish includes 1 million preserved specimens from all around the world.

name: Northwest African American Museum
description: Now a museum, once the site of the longest act of civil disobedience in United States history.

name: Bradner Gardens Park
description: This multi-functional park is a marvel of civic engagement.

name: Armory
description: A community gathering place that once housed half-ton tanks and the World's Fair.

name: Wake - Richard Serra
description: This sculpture forces visitors to confront their relationship with space.

name: Cal Anderson Park
description: A large AIDS Memorial Pathway art installation provides a moment for quiet contemplation in this public park.

name: NH
description: NHL

name: Lake View Cemetery
description: home of Bruce & Brandon Lee

name: Psychic Chicken of Seattle
description: Deep into the lower floors of Pike Place, find a date with fowl fate.

name: Fantagraphics Bookstore And Gallery
description: A bookstore with an entire room dedicated to damaged and forlorn comic books.

name: Georgetown Trailer Park Mall
description: This offbeat trailer park is home to vintage peddlers, local artists, indie makers, and more.

name: Deep Sea Sugar And Salt
description: This fog-enshrouded, antique corner store sells individual slices of wedding-fancy layer cakes from a window.

name: Majestic Bay Theatres
description: Continuing a tradition of movie magic on the site of America’s oldest continually operating movie theatre.

name: University of Washington School of Music (MUS)
description: home to harry partch's musical instruments - A collection of odd-shaped and quirky sounding instruments handmade by a midcentury inventor-composer.

name: The Spheres
description: The tech giant built three enormous glass orbs in Seattle so employees could work inside a rainforest greenhouse.The spheres are open to visitors on the first and third Saturday of each month. While public admission to the facility is free, those interested must make a reservation. The tours, as one might expect, are popular.

name: Seattle's Giant Sequoia Tree
description: This grand old 80-foot sequoia towers above the buildings in the city’s retail center.

name: Kurt Cobain Memorial Bench
description: A sliver of nostalgia in Seattle's Viretta Park.

name: Panama Hotel and Tea House
description: This historic building provides a powerful glimpse into the lives of Japanese Americans forced to relocate during World War II.

name: Zoo Tavern
description: One of the only cooperatively owned bars in the nation wears its eclectic history on its walls.

name: Seattle City Light Denny Substation
description: The Denny Substation has been called "the coolest substation in the world" and sits in a densely populated Seattle neighborhood.

name: Plymouth Pillars Park
description: The four tall pillars once marked the entrance of the historic Seattle church that fought for women's suffrage and civil rights.

name: Salty Dog Pottery
description: Artistic Oasis in Industrial Ballard.

name: Carl S. English Jr. Botanical Garden
description: A young botanist's horticultural vision realized through a lifetime of planting, tending, and collecting seeds.

name: "The Fin Project" by John T. Young (Public Art Installation)
description: Old submarine parts have been converted into faux whale fins.

name: Wedgwood Rock
description: This quiet neighborhood is also home to a 700-ton rock transported by the last Ice Age.

name: Fremont Bridge
description: From a neon Rapunzel to a bike traffic meter to a street fair color scheme, the most opened drawbridge in the US is a veritable art gallery.

name: JP Patches and Gertrude Statue site
description: Leave a button on the jacket of this iconic Seattle clown.

name: Mox Boarding House
description: A busy cafe better known for board games than food.

name: Egan's Ballard Jam House
description: This jazz venue welcomes performers nightly and students daily.

name: Pioneer Building
description: NHL "The Pioneer Building is a Richardsonian Romanesque building built in 1892. The Pergola was formerly a cable car stop built in 1909,[15] and the Seattle Totem Pole, which was originally carved around 1790, was stolen from a Tlingit village, and presented to the city of Seattle by its Chamber of Commerce in 1899"

name: Inscape Arts and Cultural Center
description: This former INS center is now home to a thriving community of artists, from performers to painters to architects.

name: The Great Hall at Union Station
Chapel - Ft. Lawton Historic District
description: This Puget Sound military post has a long, turbulent history as a gateway to the Pacific.

name: Lakeridge Park
description: Deadhorse canyon little hike

name: Montlake Spite House
description: This tiny home built on revenge appears to be scarcely wider than a Volkswagen.

name: Valley of the Gnomes
description: The classic lawn figurine now claims this wooded area as home.

name: Jimi Hendrix Memorial
description: The final resting place of one of the most sensational guitar players of all time was created only after his father got the rights to his music.

name: Renton Library
description: This unique library spans a mighty river.

name: Earthwork Robert Morris
description: Tasked with beautifying a disused stretch of industrial land one artist filled a hole with grass.

name: Dune Peninsula at Point Defiance Park
description: A massive environmental project transformed this former smelter into a beautiful park.

name: Japanese Language School Memorial
description: This site was a school and a center of Japanese-American life before internment.

name: We Honor a Hero
description: This statue honors Marvin Klegman, a heroic child who died while saving another boy's life in a 1949 earthquake, and shares his long untold story.

name: Top of the Ocean Historical Marker
description: This waterfront restaurant was the life of the party until a crime syndicate burned it to the ground.

name: Spanish Steps
description: A Roman holiday is closer than you think when you use this 1916 staircase inspired by Rome's Piazza di Spagna.

name: Old St Peter's Church
description: The oldest remaining building in Tacoma was once the home of the "oldest bell tower" in America.

name: Job Carr Cabin Museum
description: This Old Town cabin tells the story of Tacoma's settlement through a replica of its first non-Native building.

name: Tacoma Union Station
description: Tacoma's historic Beaux-Arts train station is now a federal courthouse featuring large-scale glass sculptures by artist Dale Chihuly.

name: Chihuly Bridge of Glass
description: A beautiful footbridge with over 2,000 glass sculptures along the walls and ceiling.

name: Buffalo Soldiers Museum
description: Sharing the often-overlooked story of America's Black soldiers.

name: Brown & Haley Factory Store
description: This century-old confectioner's outlet store was plucked right out of the Seattle World's Fair.

name: Sanford & Son Antiques!
description: This three-story antique market and curiosity emporium claims to be "the largest singly owned antique shop in the Pacific Northwest."

name: Bob's Java Jive
description: Tacoma’s 25-foot coffee pot music spot has served up over 80 years of concrete kitsch.

name: Acacia Memorial Park & Funeral Home
description: Grand mausoleum with acres of stained glass

name: Sylvan Grove Theater and Columns
description: a small grassy field that was initially used for plays. Along the far end, which served as the stage, are four hand-fluted cedar Ionic columns that were salvaged from a portico in the original downtown University of Washington campus that was demolished in 1908. This beautiful, peaceful space is usually empty during weekdays and is perfect for picnics.

name: Wall of Misfit Art
description: A mesmerizing amount of crazy art is attached to the side of this house on Seattle's Phinney Ridge, bringing smiles to those who venture down the driveway to take a look.

name: Bruun Idun - Way of the Bird King
Flying Heritage & Combat Armor Museum
description: Three hangars filled with meticulously restored aircraft and armored vehicles.

name: Giant Cedar Stump
description: At a rest stop north of Seattle, the trunk of an ancient tree.

name: Hotel Sorrento
description:
The Hotel Sorrento is the oldest hotel in Seattle to serve continuously as a hotel since its construction—in this case, 1909. Even after a few restorations, it maintains a grand appearance, with an Italian renaissance exterior wrapping around a central courtyard. Inside, enjoy a cocktail or snack by the fire.

The Hotel Sorrento is also, according to legend, extremely haunted. The alleged ghost is that of Gertrude Stein’s partner Alice B. Toklas, and she appears to be benevolent; the fireside lounge is cozy and a great place for a few snacks or beverages.
